data.title: Jacques Anatole Francois Thibault
data.meta_description: Poems by Jacques Anatole Francois Thibault. Anatole France won the nobel prize for literature in 1921.
data.text:
To Théophile Gautier

On her short story of "Arria Marcella"

The hollow of a charming breast that the ashes molded

Was the cup where you drank this eloquent intoxication,

Who, under the narrow portico with acanthus scrolls,

Brought up in the crimson Arria Marcella.

Sur sa nouvelle d' " Arria Marcella "

Le creux d'un sein charmant que la cendre moula

Fut la coupe où tu bus cette ivresse éloquente,

Qui, sous l'étroit portique aux volutes d'acanthe,

Fit surgir dans la pourpre Arria Marcella.

Analysis (ai): The poem celebrates a work by another author, "Arria Marcella." It focuses on a specific aspect of the original work: Arria Marcella's emergence from a small space into a grand presence. This moment is described through a sensual image of a breast's imprint in ashes, suggesting a transformation from something intimate to something extraordinary.

The poem's brevity and imagery reflect the aesthetic principles of the time period, which emphasized conciseness and evocative language. Its focus on a specific aspect of the original work also aligns with the trend toward fragmentary and subjective expression in art and literature.

Compared to the author's other works, this poem exhibits a similar attention to sensual detail and evocative language. However, its specific focus on a moment of transformation and the use of a specific image distinguish it from other works.
